title: Asia & Indian Ocean Charter Guide: Where to Cruise in Paradise
content:encoded:
The paradise islands of Seychelles, Mauritius and the Maldives are welcoming charter destinations along with Thailand, parts of Indonesia and Malaysia.

As the demand for charter holidays in far-flung places increases, more and more charter companies are now operating further afield, opening up new and interesting destinations for UK and European charter sailors. However, you will find that flotillas are much less common than in the Mediterranean, although there are plenty of bareboat, skippered and by-the-cabin charter options.

The Indian Ocean archipelagos such as the Seychelles, the Maldives, Madagascar, Mauritius and Zanzibar with their coconut palm tree-lined castaway islands and white powder sand beaches are what charter holiday dreams are made of. The area is scattered with small islands and cays and, with so many coral reefs, it is a particularly popular part of the world for diving enthusiasts.

Whale sharks and manta rays can be spotted year-round migrating around the atolls in the Maldives hoovering up microplankton. There are also 20 different species of dolphin and five species of sea turtle. If visiting the Seychelles, take a trip ashore to see the rare black parrot or the giant tortoises. Sperm and humpback whales migrate through the Indian Ocean from June to late September and can be spotted off the coast of Mauritius.

Thailand with its 2,000 miles of coastline and mix of quiet bays, hidden beaches, and vibrant harbours is already a popular winter escape, so flights and transfers can be easily arranged once you have decided on a yacht and a location. Bear in mind, of course, that for Australian sailors (and tourists in general), this area is much closer to home than it is to Europeans.

In South East Asia, chartering a yacht is a great way to explore the hidden ‘treasures’ of the Andaman Sea for example with generally ‘line of sight’ navigation in the emerald waters among the craggy limestone islands, and unspoilt beaches. You’ll find the best time to visit is the drier season in Thailand from November to early March.

There is so much to discover with places like Phang Nga Bay and the Andaman Sea’s Phi Phi and Similan Islands some of the most popular. Head to Mu Koh Similan National Park for some of the best diving in the area, or sail to Khao Phing Kan (also known as James Bond Island after appearing in the 1974 James Bond movie The Man with the Golden Gun). Another interesting place to visit is the floating village of Koh Panyi.

For wildlife spotters, download the ultimate guide to the marine wildlife in the Andaman Sea.

When to go?

Malaysia and Thailand charters are best from November to February when you can expect sunshine and gentle north-easterlies. March to May can bring squally rain. while humidity can be oppressive in other months.

The Indian Ocean and places like the Seychelles offer year-round temperatures between 25°C and 30°C. April-May or October-November are good times to visit because not only are the winds generally from the south-east and average 10-20 knots but it’s also dry and not too humid.

title: Northern Europe Charter Guide: Sailing in France & Scandinavia
content:encoded:
Long summer days and sunny, interesting anchorages and marinas await those charter sailors willing to calculate tides and depths and watch the weather forecasts.

Covering Brittany, the English Channel, the North Sea Coast and the Baltic, the British yachtsman’s almanac covers much of this vast, interesting but challenging sailing area. From tidal extremes off the Brittany coast avoiding some of the busiest shipping lanes on earth and perhaps detouring via the vast Netherlands and Danish inland network you arrive in the relatively placid, rock-strewn waters of the Baltic. There is something for everyone (unless you absolutely require temperatures above 30°C!) and each region stands alone as a fascinating and varied sailing area.

Northern France, and the Channel Islands, offer some of the finest sailing waters in Europe. The tides, the weather and navigation are challenging for the inexperienced skipper, but if you like a challenge, the rewards are immense.  The coastline of northern France presents diverse sailing conditions, picturesque landscapes, and a rich maritime heritage, which is why it continues to attract seasoned sailors from around the world.

Brittany is a magnet for British sailors, thanks to its multitude of harbours and anchorages, many of which offer fantastic opportunities ashore to sample the delights of the regional seafood, cider, and crêpes.

In southern Brittany, Quiberon Bay is littered with charming places to anchor or tie up on the quayside. The Morbihan inland sea is a fantastic cruising area too, and the region is home to many prehistoric sites, as well as plenty of scenic bays, creeks, and coves.

Through the Straits of Dover, you eventually arrive in Dutch waters, which offers an inland route through the canal system. Yachts can motor and sail through villages, towns and cities with the mast upright. Further shortcuts in this region include the Kiel Canal that links the North Sea with the Baltic cutting across the Danish peninsula.

If you want to head further north to Scandinavia to experience the spectacular fjords and remote islands of Norway, or the pretty traditional Swedish villages in the south, that is an emerging destination for discerning sailors.

From the grand old city of Stockholm on Sweden’s east coast, there’s a chance to explore some of the 24,000-plus islands and islets that make up the world-famous archipelago.

With its pretty traditional fishing villages, rocky island-strewn coastline, sparkly clear water, and a host of natural harbours, Gothenburg on the west coast of Sweden is an equally delightful sailing area.

The Baltic Sea and Gulf of Bothnia charter region is becoming more and more recognised, with Helsinki, Finland, a good starting point in which to enjoy cruising the Archipelago Sea between Hanko in the east and the Åland Islands in the west.

The demand for charter holidays in Norway, especially along its west coast and the fjords, is growing too. With more and more holidaymakers seeking thrills and adventure, Tromsø is a popular starting point for a Northern Lights Arctic Circle charter to Svalbard (previously known as Spitzbergen), while Bergen is good for the cruising areas between Tananger and Trondheim.

Northern Europe Charter: When to go?

Conditions on the Atlantic side of France are best from May to September, but watch out for Atlantic swells at either end of the season.

June to September is the sailing season in Scandinavia but just three hours of darkness in the height of summer means long days.

In June the average maximum day temperature in Stockholm is 20°C, and the average wind speed is 12-14 knots from the west, with the chance of an afternoon sea breeze that can typically reach 15-20 knots. However, sailing between the fjords in Norway can be gusty and experience is advisable.

title: Turkey Charter Guide: Exploring the Turkish Coastline by Yacht
content:encoded:
The Mediterranean shores of Turkey are little short of sailing paradise and the yacht charter business is well established and affordable – here’s a quick destination guide for Turkish chartering.

Turkey holds a unique geographical and cultural position as the crossroads of East and West. The most exquisite sailing experiences are found in the southern regions around Marmaris and Bodrum. This area boasts an extensive coastline adorned with remnants of ancient civilizations, where Roman and Byzantine ruins dot the landscape, adding a captivating historical allure to the coastal scenery.

For many decades, sailors have been drawn to chartering yachts in Turkey, enticed by its rich history and mesmerizing coastal vistas. The region is well-equipped with a network of charter bases and flotillas, catering to the needs of seafaring adventurers seeking to explore its waters.

If you are looking to extend your cruising season to the absolute maximum, this is probably the place to go, as you are so far south that you generally get a couple more weeks of reliable sunshine compared to Greece.

The favoured starting points of Marmaris and Bodrum give opportunities for plenty of island hopping, while Gocek and Fethiye let you explore Turkey’s coastline.

The large wooden motor-sailing vessels, gulets, that operate like mini-cruise-ships, selling holidays by the cabin, are known as ‘Blue cruises’ locally and are very popular with tourists. Bareboat chartering is also very popular as is crewed and skippered chartering. 

The ecological restrictions apply to all yachts and require all waste water – even from washing up or showering – to be collected in a tank and pumped out ashore. Anchoring is widely forbidden to avoid damaging the seabed, although mooring buoys are common and running a line or two ashore is also normal, with rings attached to rocks in many places. Scuba diving is also restricted, especially on archaeological sites.

The ruins of Ephesus are located near the port of Kusadasi, on the Ionian coast and are well worth a visit. Here you can visit the Temple of Hadrian, the Library of Celsus, Gate of Hercules and more. Ancient sites can be found everywhere, some dating back 10,000 years, many standing unprotected and just part of the scenery.

Modern Turkey is a predominantly Muslim country, but the state itself is secular, and the atmosphere, especially on the coasts is not hardline: alcohol is served and women and men mix freely. Turkish is the national language but English is the second most spoken language. 

Dalaman and Bodrum airports can be reached by direct flights from the UK, or connecting flights are available from dozens of other major hubs including Istanbul, Athens and more.

Regardless of where you sail in Turkey, expect a pleasing mix of golden beaches, secluded anchorages and azure waters.

When to go?

You can expect eight or nine hours of sunshine a day and temperatures in the low to mid-20s even in April and October. In July and August, the temperatures can soar into the high 30s. The Meltemi can often take charge in afternoons in high summer, bringing winds of Force 7 from the north or north-west. It is less prevalent in off-season. The area around Bodrum generally enjoys more gentle breezes.

title: Specialist Charter Guide: Where To Go and What To Consider
content:encoded:
If you have ambitions beyond sunbathing and sight-seeing, there are charter companies offering voyages well off the beaten track or on the racecourse, as Sue Pelling explains

As the demand for adrenalin-fuelled, and adventure-style sailing holidays continues to flourish, there are more and more charter companies that now specialise. Whether it be racing at one of the iconic regattas in the Caribbean, heading north to the Arctic, south to Antarctic, or on a whisky tour of the west coast of Scotland, there’s something for everyone.

Race Fever

While it is, and has always been, possible to charter a yacht for any of the UK’s large iconic regattas such as Cowes Week, Dartmouth Royal Regatta, Round the Island Race, or the Rolex Fastnet Race, there are now so many more options available for race-hungry sunseekers looking for that ultimate challenge. Take the main Caribbean race season that runs from January to April. Good winds, constant sunshine and crystal clear, warm turquoise water are undoubtedly the Caribbean’s unique selling points and the reasons why this part of the world is hugely popular for those seeking an exciting winter escape.

These are also the reasons why so many specialist charter companies include most of the Caribbean favourites in their programmes. Antigua Sailing Week, RORC Caribbean 600, Grenada Sailing Week, St Maarten Heineken Regatta, St Barths Bucket, BVI Spring Regatta (British Virgin Islands), St Thomas International Regatta (US Virgin Islands), and Antigua Sailing Week are, without doubt, some of the most popular.

But it’s not just all about the Caribbean, there are plenty more events around the world to consider such as the Rolex Middle Sea Race (Malta), or the Rolex Sydney Hobart Race, all with charter opportunities.

If you are keen to embrace the delights of the UK racing scene, then many of the big commercial sail training schools run racing charters as well. Start your search in the busy sailing centres on the Solent – Hamble, Cowes, Portsmouth and Lymington – to discover your routes into sailing at all the key international regattas, or to organise hospitality, team building, and bespoke sailing days. Anyone looking for UK Charter, tuition or corporate regattas should find a few options available in those locations.

Experience Required?

Assuming you have a basic level of sailing experience, signing up for a place on a tuition-based race charter yacht is one of the best introductions to racing. It’s also a great option if you already have experience but are looking to improve your racing skill. Because racing is considered high risk in terms of insurance, there are only a few large companies that offer bareboat charter. But you will find many independent charter owners who are keen to share their yachts during regatta weeks.

Specialist Charters for the Adventurer

Never has there been such a choice of adventure sailing trips as there is now and these companies are based all over the country, sailing out of every port imaginable. There is a huge range of trips throughout the world aboard traditional, classic, and historic sailing craft that offer adrenaline-filled fun including tall ships and expedition yachts.

If you are looking for a once-in-a-life time trip to somewhere like Antarctica or Greenland, then joining a professional company that specializes in remote areas of the world on a yacht that’s fit for purpose, is unquestionably the right thing to do. Look out for voyages that combine adventure with scientific surveying work, which helps to defray the costs a bit, but reduces the luxury aspect as well. Bear in mind, some of these voyages are measured in weeks, not days and could well be life-changing adventures. Just pick a destination, an ocean, a route, or an event you’d like to attend and there is almost certainly a sailing adventure you could take on your way there or your way back. From Reykjavik to Tristan Da Cunha, there is a lifetime of voyaging on offer. 

Specialist Charter: Scotland and Ireland

The west coast of Scotland, and Ireland have always been firm favourites for slightly off the beaten track charter holidays – in particular tours of the whisky distilleries. There are photography cruises available and the rise and rise of open water swimming has created a whole new market for unusual destinations at unusual times of the year. 

Finally, for a taste of more sedate cruising, aboard a classic yacht on the Norfolk Broads, Broads Sailing Holidays (aka Oliver’s Sailing Holidays) has plenty to offer. With three different sized traditional Broads gaff-rigged classics to choose from, this holiday offers the perfect opportunity not only to enjoy the delights of the Broads, but to also give you the chance to learn the skill of sailing a gaff-rigged boat in a relaxed environment.

content:encoded:
Some charter companies’ main assets – the fleet of yachts – are actually owned by the customers. It’s a financial balancing act, but could it work for you?

How much does it cost to charter a nearly-new yacht for a fortnight in an exotic location at high season? 

Let’s be honest – a lot of customers have to compromise and book the shoulder season for a shorter period somewhere closer to home on a considerably older yacht.

Naturally, there are always cheaper deals out there, but if you are reviewing the range of owner-charter schemes on offer, the cost to bear in mind for comparison purposes is the top-line price: the ideal exotic location on an ideal boat at the ideal time. 

Every scheme is different, but the basic idea is that you put up a lump sum towards the purchase of a fully specified charter yacht (remember the ‘advertised’ cost of new vessels on the open market won’t include sails, electronics, lines, fenders, safety gear etc) and at the end of a set period (up to 5 years), you either take ownership (usually incurring a second payment) or sell the yacht and recoup some of the original outlay. 

Some companies require less money up front and then simply keep the yacht at the end of the contract and sell it themselves or continue to use it for chartering, which removes the uncertainty about recouping the money. 

The lump sum is likely to be no more than 50% of the cost of the brand new boat. Most will sweeten the deal by sharing the profit made out of the chartering. Most deals include ‘free’ sailing weeks aboard your own boat or an equivalent size and style at one of the company’s other bases. The less ‘peak season’ your weeks are, the more you get.

Dream Yachts runs a huge yacht ownership scheme – it is in fact a separate company to the charter business – and is in the process of rewriting its ownership offers. The blog on the company’s website features a young German couple who stumbled across the idea of living aboard and circumnavigating the globe before they had even learned to sail. 

So they learned how to sail over the duration of their 5-year contract with the company, trying out multiple styles and sizes of yacht in locations all over the globe, then took ownership of their own 40ft catamaran and set off on their own adventure full-time. They sailed 210 days in the first four years of the contract, including 91 days of ‘last-minute’ offers. They sailed 22 different catamarans out of 12 bases worldwide and appear to have made the absolute most out of the deal on offer.

But how would it work for a retired couple, who enjoy travelling and chartering (not just the sailing, but also the sightseeing and swimming), but can’t take advantage of every last-minute deal and don’t fancy a chilly week in late October in northern Croatia?

I spoke to a couple, Geoff and Annie, who spent 10 years as owner charterers: 5 years with Sunsail and 5 years with Dream, handing back the boats on both occasions, leaving them with fond memories and no stress or hassle whatsoever.

Q: What advice would you give to prospective owner-charterers?

  1. Think carefully about taking ownership of a boat overseas (rather than returning it or selling it). Look out for VAT that may become due, plus marina fees and insurance that you immediately become liable for.
  2. Also, consider the condition the boat is likely to be in when it’s returned to you. Five seasons of chartering creates a good deal of wear and tear, which needs to be budgeted for.
  3. Check out all the different types of contract on the market. There are a lot of options.
  4. Look at how many boats of your ‘contracted’ size the company already has in various locations. If your boat is smaller than the majority of the fleet you’ll end up having to pay to ‘level up’ for a lot of your ‘free weeks’ – especially if you’re going at peak season. The alternative is that you can book the smaller boats more than 12 months in advance, but that doesn’t help you in your first year. Presumably the same advice would apply to owners of the largest boats in the fleet too – you might end up ‘slumming it’ on smaller vessels more often than you’d like.

Our 10 years ended up costing us £5k per year for the contract and we averaged a little over 3 trips a year. Of course, each holiday incurred flights, food and other fees, but we felt like we got a lot of sailing and travel experiences without the hassle of owning and maintaining a boat.

Thailand, French Polynesia and the Whitsunday Islands were the ‘once in a lifetime’ trips, plus there were multiple Caribbean holidays and Mediterranean charters galore.’

Q: And do you have any general chartering advice for people thinking of booking in the near future?

A charter week is actually only five days quite often: Day 1 doesn’t actually go anywhere and Day 6 is often about getting back to base, so there’s no risk of being late. So the advice is to seriously consider chartering for more than a week where possible, especially in locations that are a long distance from home. 

Also, the comprehensive insurance that charter companies offer makes for a more relaxing sail especially in busy areas like the Med with challenging moorings. This isn’t cheap but does reduce the stress.

title: The Importance of Safety Gear: Tom Cunliffe’s Word of Warning
content:encoded:
Safety gear pros and cons can be a chilling subject but it pays to not only be aware of requirements but also understand the consequences of your own actions… 

Dating as I do from a different era, I have to say that I’ve never been deeply interested in safety gear. Of course I applaud the ultimate in safety, the RNLI and the SAR heroes who are always there for us when things go wrong, but my philosophy has always been one of taking every precaution to keep Old Man Danger at bay in the first place rather than assuming it’s my right to be saved if my efforts fail. My first priority lies in maintaining the boat as well as I can. Keeping off lee shores is a mantra. Looking after the charts and the paper logbook sorts out the navigation, while understanding my survival options if I find myself offshore in a storm is axiomatic. One policy straight from the gut is always to have a contingency plan up my sleeve where engine failure might result in an emergency, and I always remind people not to fall over the side. We clip on when this is an unavoidable possibility, and wear a lifejacket too. 

The fact that a radio to call for help is last on my list dates from the days when I crossed oceans with no comms at all. I was alone under God, which led to an innate assumption of self-reliance. This wasn’t because I had special talents; it was just that there was no choice.

Expanding this list would fill a small book so I won’t bore you with any more, but you’ll have noticed that the uppermost thing in my mind as I cast off for a day sail is not to remember to wear my lifejacket. The truth is that when the weather is fair you could put safe money on it staying in its locker. I do have a self-inflating, up-to-date unit for when conditions demand it. As soon as I start to think, ‘I don’t like the look of this…’ it’s on and fastened, crutch strap and all. After half a century following this procedure I’m still here to tell the tale, so there can’t be a lot wrong with it. 

‘Where’s your lifejacket?!’ warble the self-appointed guardians of my fate who comment on my Youtube videos or the occasional TV appearance when I’ve managed to persuade the director that I cannot be seen kitted up for Cape Horn on a four-foot deep canal. The honest response must surely be, ‘None of your business. It’s my life not yours and, for the record, I plan to die in my bed,’ but I try to be more polite. What’s certain is that, having made this confession in a prominent yachting magazine, I’ll receive condemnation backed up by alarming statistics. 

I would never be less than supportive of anybody who chooses to wear safety gear whenever they are afloat, but it doesn’t suit everyone. Sailors in the Caribbean and other warm-weather venues revel in the boisterous tradewind seas largely without wearing lifejackets. There is no onus on them to explain why, although suntan and water temperature have a lot to do with it. Things are different in temperate and cold-water locations, but it doesn’t alter my view that when to use one should remain a matter of personal choice and common sense. 

Research in America a few years back revealed that more people drown in their baths than while they are sailing the seas. Whether this interesting statistic was derived on aggregate or pro rata was unclear, but it begged the delightful conclusion that we all should don our PFDs before settling in for a relaxing soak with the rubber duck and the bath salts. 

Back in the real world of modern safety aids, I recently attended a presentation put on by TeamO. In 2011, a UK sailor lost his life when he fell overboard even though apparently safely tethered to a race boat. The yacht continued to move after losing way and the poor chap was dragged face-down in the water. Despite valiant efforts by his fellow crew members, he drowned. Along with a number of other incidents this got Oscar Meade and his sister Lauren thinking. Oscar is no ordinary sailor, having completed a singlehanded transatlantic race at 18. Together, they came up with the idea for TeamO and what they now call a BackTow Lifejacket. This has two USPs: the disposition of its buoyancy bags and its ‘back tow’ feature. A casualty in the water being drawn along by the chest with his mouth towards the oncoming stream and his lungs filling, has only to grab a handle at chest level and the attachment point of the tether will move around to a safe spot on his back. This flips his body painlessly so his face is now looking at the sky. The disposition of buoyancy is also unique and assists the ‘pull’ in lifting the head and shoulders clear of the water. In this mode it is possible to be dragged in relative safety. The system is also said to be superior for lifting a casualty back to the deck on a halyard.  

The lifejacket market has some big players in it, and grabbing a share was far from easy, but TeamO kept the faith. The BackTow Lifejacket and harness was launched in Spring 2017, and a good thing too.

Over lunch, some enlightening conversation arose among an eclectic company of sailors, journalists and the manufacturers. The subject is always awash with anecdote, but one story struck home. It was about today’s jackets which self-inflate as soon as they are immersed in water. It’s easy to see this as a benefit with no downside, but things are never that simple. As we munched our prawn sandwiches, we were regaled with a lively yarn about a medium-sized boat during last year’s windy Round the Island Race. Blasting along under spinnaker, the helm and the sheet-man got out of sync and lost control. She broached comprehensively and ended up briefly on her side. When she righted herself half the crew were in the water bobbing merrily in their self-inflated lifejackets. Unfortunately, the knockdown had also inflated the rest of the jackets for good measure. The hands still on board set about rescuing their shipmates, but their inflated lifejackets saw them blundering around like a bunch of drunks on a Saturday night spree. One of them who’d been ‘sitting out’ between the guardrails was jammed there by his airbags and also had to be rescued. None of the casualties in the water was unconscious so they all could have activated their lifejackets by pulling the cord. Makes you wonder, doesn’t it? I once had a self-inflating jacket go off when I slipped into the bottom of a dinghy with a few inches of water in it. The shock would have given a less robust individual a heart attack. 

I must say that my own preference is for a gas-powered lifer which doesn’t inflate until I pull the string. Whenever I promote this point of view, I always take a heavy dose of flak based on the assumption that a casualty will have been wiped out by a gybing boom, knocked unconscious, and be in no position to yank the tab. It’s hard to argue with that, except that only a small percentage of those going over the wall are in fact already unconscious. There’s no getting away from the reflex in-drawing of breath when the body suddenly hits cold water,  however. This can result in half a lung-full if your luck’s out; the instant buoyancy boost of auto-inflation may then alleviate the possibility, but that’s about it on the plus side. 

It’s a fascinating subject which, in the end, boils down to how concerned you are about the remote possibility of losing your life in this way when seen in the context of drowning in your bath or being wiped out by a left-hand drive truck in the M6 contraflow. If it remains top of your priority list, the sensible answer is to have everyone lifejacketed and clipped on at all times. As for me, I’ve assessed the risk. My life’s experience tells me that the contingency is so unlikely that I choose my safety gear with care and wear it when I feel I need it, not every day as a matter of course.

content:encoded:
Veteran charter skipper Tom Fletcher explains how to avoid some of the classic chartering mistakes.

The ‘5 Ps’ is one of the oft quoted sailing tuition maxims: proper preparation prevents poor performance. It’s an expression that can be relevant to pretty much anything though, not just approaching a MOB under sail!

Nowadays I spend a lot less time on the water, and a lot more time in the Sail Ionian office replying to guests’ enquiries about charters. Proper planning and research can reap huge rewards during your charter, from boat selection and equipment to itineraries and activities. Preparation is often rushed as a holiday is booked though. Whether you’re a foodie and want to try the local delicacies (lentils and a famous salami for Lefkada, since you ask), visit local vineyards, hike in the hills, or follow in the footsteps of Odysseus, you are chartering for the culture and the place, not just the sailing. Though a lot of guests will come simply to spend time sailing – which is a virtue in itself, to be fair – I do feel they miss out on seeing the islands, as the only time they spend ashore is for dinner each evening. My advice is to focus on something different each time you charter. One week could be about nature and wildlife, the next time could be focused on history and culture. It will give you a different route away from the main shipping lanes and allow you to see different corners of a cruising area. 

Number 5: Not getting value for your money

Not enough people ask about all the extras that are available to them. Sail Ionian have a raft of additional services aimed at various needs: from flotillas to free stern to mooring practice, to a day with a skipper, SUP rental, upgraded RIB options, even 220v fan rental!

Most charter companies won’t have big mark ups on these add-ons. They are meant to differentiate from the competition and attract business so they’re not usually high value. They can all add huge benefits to a holiday. For example, many of our guests will take the free Med mooring practice session, but not many opt for a day with a skipper. Yes, there’s a charge for the full day, but the value that you get out of that day of mooring and long lining practice, far outweighs an hour of the basics. It can open up a vast number of bays and make it much easier to moor in busy harbours, changing the whole itinerary of not just this charter, but of future ones too. When making a booking, don’t forget to ask what else the company is offering, or if they have anything they recommend that a lot of people opt for. 

In conclusion, if you don’t have the time to prepare fully for a charter, lean on the company you are booking with. They should be very familiar with all the information you need to know and be able to advise in an efficient manner. Just spend a little time at the start of the process to decide what is important to you, what else would be useful, and how you want it to be guided, and then select the best response depending on your needs.

title: Sustainable Yacht Charters: Finding Responsible Companies
content:encoded:
Charter companies are becoming more environmentally aware writes Sue Pelling. Here are the some of the companies working towards more sustainable yacht charters.

There is no doubt that sustainable travel practices can make a substantial difference in protecting our planet, which is why, as we grow more environmentally aware, the call for sustainable tourism is on the increase.

The sailing holiday charter sector was one of the first to understand the detrimental effects some of its practices would have on the planet, which is why many charter companies heeded their responsibilities by making changes to the way they run their businesses. 

Sunsail, and The Moorings for example have their Ocean Promise campaigns to reduce their carbon footprint, as do companies like Seafarer which has its own Responsible Travel policy. Even small initiatives such as switching to the use of marine safe cleaning products, campaigning for the abolishment of single use water bottles, and motivating guests to contribute towards reducing their own environmental footprint including air travel carbon offsetting, can add up to make a huge difference.

Dream Yacht Worldwide, one of the world’s leading ocean tourism companies, and Fountaine Pajot, global designer and boat builder of leading-edge luxury catamarans, together launched the Aura 51 Smart Electric catamaran with intelligent on-board energy management system.

The two companies have a joint ambition of achieving an all-electric yacht offering and zero carbon emissions by 2030.

Sail Ionian based on the island of Lefkada, Greece is another company proud to be driving green energy solutions. It has already upgraded the majority of its fleet with solar panels and electric outboards, and more recently it has introduced lithium batteries to 35 per cent of its charter fleet, as well as installing solar panels on most of its yachts.

Tom Fletcher says Sail Ionian is always pushing technical developments and the company is currently working on installing air conditioning running from solar panels and lithium batteries on small yachts. “Previously, air conditioning has only been available on larger yachts, and could not be run from batteries, only with a generator or shore power connection. This is a charter market world-wide first.”

Plain Sailing is a charter company that continues to make eco-friendly choices ranging from solar lighting to running servers on renewable energy, and sustainable travel. They have also signed up to the RYA Green-Blue pledge, and, through the use of carbon offsetting, have managed to become a carbon negative operation.

Harnessing the power of the wind alone is the most effective way to enjoy a holiday without harming the planet. Classic Sailing the Cornwall-based company that runs adventure sailing holidays aboard classic yachts and ships in UK, Europe, and worldwide has had its Eco Policy in place since 1997. For over a quarter of a centure, this company has been committed in its efforts to reduce the environmental harm of its activities by using less energy and reducing air, land, and sea pollution wherever possible.

VentureSail runs similar adventures on classic and historic vessels, and strives to ensure its ventures are environmentally friendly. This company is also proud of its eco-tourism pledge and its initiatives to help save the planet, which includes planting a tree for each holiday booking made… nice touch.

title: Guide to Chartering in Greece: Affordable Mediterranean Cruising
content:encoded:
White sails on the wine dark sea – Affordable yacht chartering was practically invented in this Mediterranean paradise and the islands remain welcoming to sailing tourists

In the 1970s, Greece spearheaded the flotilla and charter culture, and to this day, remains a popular destination. It’s no surprise considering Greece offers diverse sailing conditions suitable for all skill levels and budgets. Nestled within breathtaking coastlines, with crystal-clear turquoise anchorages, excellent cuisine, and rich cultural heritage, Greece continues to attract generation after generation.

Greece is also well served by budget airlines – in fact it has more than a dozen airports and there are easy connections to all the major charter bases. With around 6,000 Greek Islands and more than 9,000 miles of coastline, there’s always somewhere new to visit even for island-hopping regulars, and the industry is so well established in the region that it’s very well prepared to cater for all types of sailors and their budgets. If you’re looking for a competitively priced holiday therefore, in a friendly flotilla, a skippered yacht or a bareboat, then Greece will deliver.

From a sailor’s perspective, the region is split into six principal areas: the Ionian Sea, the Saronic Gulf, the Cyclades, the Sporades and Dodecanese, the Northern Sporades, and Crete. The Aegean Sea lies to the east of Greece, and the lonian/Peloponnese to the west.

Wind conditions vary considerably but generally get stronger as you head eastwards across the Aegean. So, for relaxed cruising consider the short leg/island-hopping option in areas such as the Ionian, Saronic Gulf and Peloponnese. The islands are just far enough apart to enjoy a good sail, while allowing plenty of time to enjoy the stunning anchorages, beaches and taverna culture. For more of a challenge the Aegean, Dodecanese in the south-east, or even Crete are a good option because the longer passages between the islands – sometimes 30-40nm – can take the best part of a day to sail depending on weather conditions.

The weather during May, June, and September is perfect as it’s typically not excessively hot, the winds remain gentle, and the anchorages are usually less crowded. July and August are the hot months and the winds are more sporadic. The season continues until early October, when the water is the warmest but the weather less predictable.

Northerly winds known as the Meltemi occur in the summer months and can reach up to 30 knots in areas like the corridor between the Dodecanese and Cycladic islands, which could be unsettling for novice crews.

With so much choice, it’s sometimes hard to know where to go on a Greek sailing holiday, but there are a multitude of charter operators big and small who will be happy to share their knowledge and advice.

When to Charter in Greece?

Although it is possible to charter a yacht between November and March, the main charter season is between late April and early October. While the rainfall in summer is minimal, there might be a few unpredictable weeks at either end of the charter season, so keep that in mind when booking.

Temperatures are consistent, ranging from the low 20s in May and October through to the high 30s in July and August. From April, things settle down and the lonian is noted for its predictable winds: calm in the morning, then 15-20 knots from 1400 until sun-down. The Saronic Gulf has moderate winds, and in the Aegean you’ll feel the power of the Meltemi from mid-May to September.

title: Charter Destination Guide: Cruising in Italy, Sardinia and Corsica
content:encoded:
History and culture combine to make The Tyrrhenian Sea and the Italian coastline one of the most cosmopolitan but charming charter sailing areas on earth.

Italy boasts many wonderful cruising grounds in a relatively small geographic area, with the Amalfi Coast, Sardinia’s Costa Smeralda, Sicily’s Aeolian Islands and The Tuscan Archipelago just a few of the highlights. Interestingly, the Island of Corsica is one of the poorest regions of France, reliant on tourism for much of its income, and large stretches of its coastline are undeveloped. Yet just to the south, Sardinia is relatively well off compared to the rest of southern Italy.  

Sardinia’s Costa Smeralda boasts stunning beaches and crystal-clear waters ideal for relaxation and adventure. The Maddalena Archipelago in particular, on the north-east corner, offers great coastal sailing and scenic anchorages. 

Corsica offers peace, tranquillity and exciting sailing and you can also be sure of a warm welcome ashore. Nestled between the south of France and Sardinia, this rugged island with its 600-plus miles of coastline, and hundreds of miles of fine white sandy beaches has charter bases in Calvi, Ajaccio, Bonifacio and Macinaggio. The west coast from Cap Corse to Ajaccio is the place to head for. Drop the hook near the Réserve Naturel de Scandola and you may spot seals and dolphins.

What is now mainland Italy was, until the mid-1800s a series of separate nations, or city states – often at war with each other. This means that the look and feel of the country can change quite dramatically from region to region without travelling huge distances. 

The Tuscan islands of Elba, Capraia, Pianosa, Giglio, and Montecristo are popular destinations for history enthusiasts and wine lovers. This is a popular area but not as frighteningly expensive as the Cote d’Azur to the north or the Amalfi coast.

Further south in the Bay of Naples, you’ll find the enchanting islands of Capri and Ischia within easy reach, along with the charming ports of Positano and Sorrento. They’re glamorous but very expensive in high season.

The Amalfi Coast was listed as a World Heritage Site in 1997 and is perfect for those seeking picturesque towns and luxury experiences. Marinas are abundant but bear in mind that in high summer these destinations are very popular, so booking is essential and be prepared to pay.  

Sicily’s Aeolian Islands off the northern coast are best for exploring volcanic landscapes.

Don’t ignore the Adriatic, where you can pick up a local charter yacht and enjoy the coastline up as far as Venice and Trieste, experiencing a grand arrival by yacht along the Lido with Saint Mark’s Basilica as a backdrop.

On the French Mediterranean coastline, marinas are often jam-packed and even some of the protected anchorages along the coast have limited space. Saint-Tropez, Antibes, and Monaco on the Rivièra are the best places for glitz and glamour, but ferociously expensive. The Isles d’Hyères – a group of islands near the mainland town of Hyeres are a cost-effective alternative to the Côte d’Azur, with good anchoring, and a marina in Porquerolles.

When to go?

Italy and its islands have mostly fine weather from April to September. In the height of summer, a calm in the morning can often develop into a strong afternoon breeze and because the water is fairly shallow, you’ll find a short chop will appear. The Strait of Bonifacio between north Sardinia and Corsica, around the Aeolian Islands, and in the Strait of Messina between Sicily and the mainland are known for big winds. Sicily’s north-west tip can be lively too.

The south coast of France, including Corsica, is usually mild in April, May, and September, but the Mistral can blow continuously for two to three days across the Gulf of Lion.
